captions.text:
Because you're not
the chosen brother, eli.

'twas paul
who was chosen.

He found me and told me
about your land.
You're just a fool.

Why are you
talking about paul?

I did what your
brother couldn't.

Don't say this to me.
I broke you
and I beat you.

It was paul
told me about you.

He's the prophet.
He's the smart one.
He knew what was there

And he found me
to take it out
of the ground.

Know what
the funny thing is?
Listen, listen.

I paid him $10,000
cash in hand.
Just like that.

He has his own company now.
Prosperous little business.

Three wells producing,
$5,000 a week.
(crying)

Stop crying,
you sniveling ass.
Stop your nonsense.

You're just
the afterbirth, eli.
No.

That slithered out
on your mother's filth.
No.

They should've put
you in a glass jar
on the mantelpiece.

Where were you
when paul was suckling
at his mother's teat?
Where were you?

Who was nursing you,
poor eli?
One of bandy's sows?

That land has been had.
Nothing you can
do about it. It's gone.

If you would just
take this lease...
You lose.
Drainage!
Drainage, eli, you boy.

Drained dry.
I'm so sorry.
If you have a milkshake
And I have a milkshake,

And I have a straw,
there it is.

That's the straw,
you see?
Watch it.

Now my straw
reaches across the room

And starts to
drink your milkshake.
I drink your milkshake!
(slurping)
I drink it up!
Don't bully me, daniel.
(screaming)

title: I Drink Your Milkshake! - There Will Be Blood (7/8) Movie CLIP (2007) HD

comments.author: JD3Psilocybin

comments.text:
SPOILER IF YOU HAVE NOT SEEN FILM


What Daniel Day Lewis' character is alluding to with the milkshake analogy 
is that the land he had given or sold to Eli which Eli THOUGHT was full of 
oil had in fact been drained of oil via wells on other properties 
presumably by sideways drilling.  The two milkshakes thus equate to the two 
parcels of land and the oil on them.  Lewis' character "drank the 
milkshake" (oil) of the other guy's land via a long straw (pipe)..﻿

comments.author: janeswurld

comments.text:
The theme behind the name is actually very present throughout the story, 
although blood might be bettered referred to as human suffering in general 
rather than just physical pain but that's beyond the scope of this 
discussion. The bloody bowling pin in this scene really cements the meaning 
at the end but over the course of the film the miners killed, plainview's 
own injury, his sons injury, and of course the murder of his brothers 
criminal friend all contribute to the blood spilled on his economic 
warpath. Surely I'm forgetting other instances but you get the idea. I 
think the intended conclusion is that uninhibited capitalism, void of 
regulation and ethics, ultimately produces a lot of blood, suffering, and 
primarily victimizes those who knowingly engage in the risks. His son is 
obviously unaware of the risks and the innocence of the miners killed could 
be contested, but again that's another discussion. 
I'm actually surprised the crazy right wing conservatives of America did 
not attack this story but I guess most of them are too slow to understand 
the themes and motifs being presented here about the dangers of truly free 
markets.

comments.text:
I thought this was a very good movie, probably great, but I would not call 
this one of the greatest ever made. That is a bit of an exaggeration. 
Daniel Day Lewis deserved the Oscar hands down, no one could touch him but 
what I notice is that he tends to go over-the-top or "chewing the scenery" 
with some of his performances, like Gangs of New York. Jack Nicholson is 
almost the same way. Would I call Daniel Day Lewis the best actor who ever 
lived? I don't think so. But a very talented one yes, pretty much up in par 
with Meryl Streep and Jack Nicholson.﻿

comments.text:
The man is undoubtedly a monster. And yet, for some reason, the audience 
can feel good basking in his hatred, intense hatred for everyone. Because 
sometime people are utterly disgusting, and you want nothing more than them 
to fail and suffer, or even die﻿
comments.author: TheSuperfluousMan

comments.text:
+TheSuperfluousMan If you rewatch the movie, you'll see that Plainview does 
actually have some humanity; but he is repeatedly turned bitter and jaded, 
partially by circumstance and partially by his own avarice.
When he first adopts HW, you can clearly see how affectionate he is with 
the boy; and even though he opportunistically leverages the "family" angle 
for his business.
Plainview has incredible difficulty communicating vulnerability, and so he 
falls back on hostility when he feels alienated or rejected. This is why 
him being vulnerable around someone he thought was his brother was so 
significant; this is why his trust being violated by that man compounded 
his jadedness and reclusiveness.

I don't think Plainview is as villainous as people make him out to be if 
you watch a few key scenes like when he stops Mary and tells her hell take 
care of her if she keeps being hit by her father and the scene where you 
can see his pain over whether or not HW has a big enough room. Because you 
learn (when he tells Henry that the hollister house would make him sick if 
he saw it again or the scene where he cries reading his brothers journal) 
that he hates people and is extremely competitive in nature was just really 
a by product of his childhood

comments.text:
I think the only reason people hate this movie is because the main 
character turn out to be kind of an asshole. Everyone expects to see 
someone who seeks fortune to be good in some sort of way. But here we see a 
greedy man who takes a child as a sweet face for business, a non believer 
of religion, and a murder. But this is what i think ﻿

comments.text:
The movie clearly portrays that he loved his son, and that he even 
confessed to his fake brother that even when he was a little kid, he wanted 
to raise children.  The moment after he says "bastard in a basket" we see 
him flash back to a time when HW was playing around with his hat, and we 
see a rare smile from Plainview.  He regrets what he said to his son, but 
because he has nothing to live for, he doesn't bother doing anything about 
it.
